Field Label: Unique identifier for a grouping of samples or runs
Unique name or identifier for biosensor protocol
Abbreviation or short label for technology
Number of samples in a sample_group used to calculate metrics
Limit of Blank (LOB).  The highest apparent analyte concentration expected to be found when a replicate of a sample containing no analyte are tested.
Field Note: Armbruster DA, Pry T. Limit of blank, limit of detection and limit of quantitation. Clin Biochem Rev. 2008 Aug;29 Suppl 1(Suppl 1):S49-52. PMID: 18852857; PMCID: PMC2556583.

Field Label: Concentration unit for limit_of_blank
Limit of Detection (LOD). The minimum amount or concentration of analyte that can be reliably distinguished from zero.
Field Note: Armbruster DA, Pry T. Limit of blank, limit of detection and limit of quantitation. Clin Biochem Rev. 2008 Aug;29 Suppl 1(Suppl 1):S49-52. PMID: 18852857; PMCID: PMC2556583.

Field Label: Concentration unit for limit_of_detection
Name of the gene used to define the concentration of a viral sample
Signal to noise ratio used to define the limit of detection in standard deviations.
Description of how limit of detection was determined.
Field Note: Example: A dilution series of heat inactivated SARS-CoV-2 virus stock (USA-WA1/2020) was prepared in natural clinical matrix (pooled nasopharyngeal swab samples eluted in VTM). Five (5) replicates were tested per dilution. The testing was performed as per the recommended instructions for use, with the virus in clinical matrix applied directly onto the Swab until the saturation of the flocked tip. The estimated LoD concentration for verification was selected as the concentration in between the dilution factor that returned 5/5 positive test outcomes (100%) and the next dilution factor that returned 0/5 positive (0%) based on the qualitative result. Source: https://www.fda.gov/media/144592/download.

Field Label: Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval for limit_of_detection.
Lower bound of confidence interval for limit_of_detection.
Upper bound of confidence interval for limit_of_detection.
Limit of Quantiation (LOQ). The minimum amount or concentration of analyte in the test sample that can be quantified with acceptable precision.
Field Note: Armbruster DA, Pry T. Limit of blank, limit of detection and limit of quantitation. Clin Biochem Rev. 2008 Aug;29 Suppl 1(Suppl 1):S49-52. PMID: 18852857; PMCID: PMC2556583.

Field Label: Concentration unit for limit_of_quantitation
Signal to noise ratio used to define the limit of quantification in standard deviations.
Description of how limit of quantition was determined.
Field Note:
COVID-19 Home Test was tested with up to a concentration
of 106.43 TCID 50 /mL of heat inactivated SARS-CoV-2 virus
(USA-WA1/2020 Isolate). Source: https://www.fda.gov/media/144592/download.

Field Label: Dynamic range min is the  lowest concentration of an analyte that can be reliably detected by the assay.
Unit of dynamic_range_min
Dynamic range ax is the heighest concentration of an analyte that can be reliably detected by the assay.
Unit of dynamic_range_max
Description of high dose hook effect.
Field Note: Example: No high dose hook effect was observed when the Ellume COVID-19 Home Test was tested with up to a concentration of 106.43 TCID 50 /mL of heat inactivated SARS-CoV-2 virus (USA-WA1/2020 Isolate). Source: https://www.fda.gov/media/144592/download.

Field Label: Test is considered positive if the assay readout is greater than or equal the non_clinical_cutoff_min value and negative if the assay readout is less than the non_clinical_cutoff_min value, e.g., cutoff value chosen from the ROC curve.
Unit of non_clinical_cutoff_min
The proportion of system-based positives; calculated as 100xTP/(TP+FN). Used for comparison with a VQA standard.
Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval for non_clinical sensitivity.
Lower bound of confidence interval for non_clinical sensitivity.
Upper bound of confidence interval for non_clinical sensitivity.
The proportion of system-based negatives; calculated as 100xTN/(TN+FP). Used for comparison with a VQA standard.
Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval for non_clinical specificity.
Lower bound of confidence interval for non_clinical specificity.
Upper bound of confidence interval for non_clinical specificity.
ROC-based performance. AUC under ROC curve.
List of false positive rate values (1-specificity)
List of true positive rate values (sensitivity)
The lowest concentration of an analyte that can be detected as positive outcome by the test system 95% of the time.
Field Note: Example: 19 out of 20 positive sample are detected as positive in an LOD panel.

Field Label: The unit of analytical_sensitivity
Field Note: Example: 19 out of 20 positive sample are detected as positive in an LOD panel.

Field Label: The slope of the calibration curve.
Field Note: Armbruster DA, Pry T. Limit of blank, limit of detection and limit of quantitation. Clin Biochem Rev. 2008 Aug;29 Suppl 1(Suppl 1):S49-52. PMID: 18852857; PMCID: PMC2556583; https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8Pe3k3fJNe8

Field Label: Unit of slope_calibration_of_curve
Description of the analytical cutoff
Test is considered positive if assay readout is geater than or equal the analytical_cutoff_min value
Unit of analytical_cutoff_min
Test is considered positive if assay readout is less than or equal the analytical_cutoff_max value
Unit of analytical_cutoff_max
Impact of variants/mutations on test results. Specificity with respect to variants/mutations compared to wildtype
Field Note: Analysis can be in silico and wet testing

Field Label: Name of organism tested for cross-reactivity against target organism
NCBI taxonomy id of organism tested for cross-reactivity against target organism
Concentration of cross-reacting organism.
Concentation unit used for cross-reacting organism.
Result of cross-reactivity test against target organism. A positive results indicates that cross-reacting organism gives a positive signal.
Description of observed cross-reactivity.
Name of the interfering substance.
Name of the entity that provided the interfering substance.
Concentration of the interfering substance.
Concentration unit  used for interfering substance.
Description of observed interference.
Field Note:
Example:  There was no interference of SARS-CoV-2 detection
observed from any of the substances tested except for
bleach which was shown to interfere at the initial
concentration of 1% v/v tested. Further testing indicated that
the highest bleach level the test system could tolerate was
0.2% v/v. Source: https://www.fda.gov/media/144592/download.

Field Label: Positive Percent Agreement (PPA). The proportion of non-reference standard positive subjects in whom the new test is positive.
Negative Percent Agreement (NPA). The proportion of non-reference standard negative subjects in whom the new test is negative.

Percentage of total subjects where the
new test and the non-reference standard agree.

A particular disease, a disease stage, health status, or any other identifiable condition within a patient, such as staging a disease already known to be present, or a health condition that should prompt clinical action, such as the initiation, modification, or termination of treatment.

The best available method for establishing the presence or absence of the target condition; the reference standard can be a single test or method, or a combination of methods and techniques, including clinical follow-up.
The subjects/patients (and specimen types) included in the study
Stratification of subjects, e.g., days since onset of symptoms, asymptomatic vs. symptomatic, co-infections, PCR Cycle Threshold, n x LOD concentration ranges for contrived samples
Identifier for a grouping of patients
Number of subject in a cohort (see cohort_id) used to calculate metrics
The expected label based on a  gold standard
Total number of positive samples
Total number of negative samples
Total number of positive samples used for the calculation and modeling.
Total number of negative samples used for the calculation and modeling.
True Positives (TP). The number of subjects/specimens with true positive test results
False Positives (FP). The number of subjects/specimens with false positive test results
True Negatives (TN). The number of subjects/specimens with true negative test results.
False Negatives (FN). The number of subjects/specimens with false negative test results
The proportion of subjects with the target condition in whom the test is positive; calculated as 100xTP/(TP+FN). Used for comparison with a reference (Gold) standard.
Field Note: PCR is Gold standard for COVID-19. For comparison with a non-reference standard use percent agreement metrics.

Field Label: Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval for clinical sensitivity.
Lower bound of confidence interval for clinical sensitivity.
Upper bound of confidence interval for clinical sensitivity.
The proportion of subjects without the target condition in whom the test is negative; calculated as 100xTN/(FP+TN).
Field Note: PCR is Gold standard for COVID-19. For comparison with a non-reference standard use percent agreement metrics.

Field Label: Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval for clinical specificity.
Lower bound of confidence interval for clinical specificity.
Upper bound of confidence interval for clinical specificity.
The proportion of test positive patients who have the target condition; calculated as 100xTP/(TP+FP)
Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval for positive predicted value.
Lower bound of confidence interval for positive predicted value
Upper bound of confidence interval for positive predicted value
The proportion of test negative patients who do not have the target condition; calculated as 100xTN/(TN+FN)
Percent used to define two-sided confidence interval for negative predicted value.
Lower bound of confidence interval or negative predicted value
Upper bound of confidence interval or negative predicted value
Description of the clinical cutoff
Test is considered positive if assay readout is geater than or equal the clinical_cutoff_min value
Unit of clinical_cutoff_min
Test is considered positive if assay readout is less than or equal the clinical_cutoff_max value
Unit of clinical_cutoff_max
The fraction of tests that gave an invalid or undetermined results and where excluded from the calculation of metrics
Description why test results where excluded from the calculation of metrics
Turnaround time for test in minutes
Unit for turnaround_time
Price per test in USD
Type of cross validation used for the statistical method used
Number of permutations performed for the cross validation of the statistical method used.
